column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1.
#Text=Introduction

#Text=In the framework of novel wireless communications systems , such as 5G or Internet of Things ( IoT ) , unmanned aerial vehicles ( UAVs ) are playing an important role for network deployment and monitoring .
#Text=For example , UAVs are being introduced as network nodes for data gathering in large areas and to extend mobile networks coverage by means of drone base stations .

#Text=Within this framework , on-site calibration and measurement of antennas for wireless communications have gained interest due to the advances in UAVs technology , which simplify the procedures for on-site measurements .
#Text=Antenna measurement in anechoic chambers provide an accurate characterization of the antenna parameters ( e. g. , radiation pattern , gain , return losses ) .
#Text=However , it must be taken into account that these parameters can be affected by the environment surrounding the place where the antenna is deployed .
#Text=For example , buildings and obstacles could result in multipath contributions that could modify the coverage .
#Text=On-site antenna measurements allow the assessment of the radiation performance of the antenna considering the influence of the surrounding environment .

#Text=The improvements in geo-referring and positioning subsystems on board the UAVs , capable of providing centimeter-level accuracy , have also enabled on-site antenna measurement at higher frequency bands .
#Text=The current state-of-the-art on on-site antenna measurement has shown the feasibility of these systems up to C-band .

#Text=The most common geo-referring and positioning subsystems that can be mounted on UAVs are global navigation satellite systems ( GNSS ) , real time kinematics ( RTK ) , inertial measurement units ( IMUs ) , laser rangefinders , photogrammetry systems and barometers .
#Text=A combination of these systems can lead to geo-referring accuracies within a few centimeters .
#Text=Ground-based laser trackers can also be used to increase accuracy by one order of magnitude .

#Text=Most of the prototypes and systems for on-site antenna measurement using UAVs are intended to operate in the far field ( FF ) region of the antenna-under-test ( AUT ) which , in the case of electrically large antennas ( e. g. , reflector antennas , mobile networks base station antennas ) can be hundreds of meters away from the AUT .
#Text=As explained in , there are some restrictions for the direct measurement of the FF pattern using UAVs , namely safety restrictions ( forbidden flight areas ) and UAV flight autonomy .

#Text=These issues can be overcome if the measurements are carried out in the near field ( NF ) region of the AUT , so that the furthest distance from the AUT to the UAV is not greater than 10 – 20 m. The feasibility of NF measurements using UAV-based systems has been proved in .
#Text=In order to recover the FF pattern of the AUT from NF measurements , near field-to-far field ( NF-FF ) transformation techniques must be applied .
#Text=For this reason , complex ( i. e. , amplitude and phase ) NF measurements are required .
#Text=However , complex NF measurements require more expensive ( and weighty ) hardware to be placed on board the UAV .
#Text=Besides , phase measurements are more sensitive to geo-referring uncertainties .
#Text=An alternative to the use of complex receivers is provided by phase retrieval techniques , capable of recovering phase information from amplitude-only measurements .
#Text=Once the phase of the field is retrieved , NF-FF transformation techniques can be applied to calculate the AUT radiation pattern .
#Text=However , NF measurements can be post-processed for antenna diagnostics ( e. g. , detection of malfunctioning elements ) .
#Text=There are two main groups of phase retrieval methods .
#Text=On the one hand , holographic techniques have been proved to be very accurate and efficient in terms of measurement time , as just one measurement surface has to be scanned .
#Text=However , these techniques require an additional hardware component ( e. g. , a reference antenna or an injected reference signal ) .
#Text=On the other hand , iterative techniques do not need additional hardware elements , but the NF radiated by the AUT must be measured on two or more acquisition surfaces .
#Text=Thus , for on-site NF antenna measurements using UAVs , the latter group of methods is more suitable , allowing a faster and easier deployment of the system .
#Text=Nevertheless , recent developments in phaseless antenna measurement techniques using a single acquisition surface are a promising solution aiming to avoid the need of two acquisition surfaces .
#Text=In , an UAV-based system for on-site antenna measurement was presented , assessing the performance of the implemented system for antenna diagnostics and characterization .
#Text=This contribution presents several novelties to improve the measurement accuracy of the system , thus enabling the characterization of high directive antennas , such as reflectors .

#Text=These improvements are ( i ) the use of a dual-channel receiver , that allows placing two receiving antennas ( probe antennas ) at two different distances onboard the UAV , thus collecting NF measurements at two different distances simultaneously ; ( ii ) the introduction of a GNSS dual-band RTK receiver , which increases positioning and geo-referring accuracy and reliability .
#Text=The former also helps to reduce the flight time , since only one flight is required to gather measurements at two different surfaces .
#Text=The later contributes to reduce the deployment time , since the convergence time ( i. e. , the time until a corrected position is obtained ) improves compared to a single-band RTK receiver .
#Text=However , several technical flaws found in the previous version of the prototype for on-site measurements that had an impact in the accuracy of the measurements have been assessed and solved .
